content.description: This is a short but classic steep hand crack.  It faces east and therefore gets morning sun.  In earlier guidebooks, it was listed as "Ironworks."
content.location: near the right end of the smooth part of the wall

climbs.name: Son Volt Arete
climbs.fa: (TR) Matt Beebe and Dave Mayville, FL: Tom Murphy and Tony Sartin, October 2006

content.description: Climb a shallow easy crack (1 bolt) to a shelf.  Clip another bolt and move directly onto the arete.  A series of powerful and technical moves to the next bolt comprise the crux of this route.  A few stances help control the pump, topped with a tricky ending.  Quite short, but with almost zero approach and easy off anchors the Son Volt Arete has alot to offer.
content.location: The Foundry is comprised of a number of small formations described in Joshua Tree West.  The Son Volt Arete is the line just right of Little Lieback on the Foundry East Face.  Start down and right of the large boulder that sits at the base.

climbs.name: Six-Pack Crack
climbs.fa: Alan Roberts, Todd Gordon, and Brian Sillasen, Jan. 1988

content.description: An offwidth and fist crack on the west face of the rock.
content.location: This is the right of two obvious wide cracks on the west face of the rock.

content.description:
Start in the same place as Vaino's Crack.

Climb right past a bolt, then up a thin crack past another bolt to the top.
content.location: Start in the same place as Vaino's Crack.

content.description:
This engaging route climbs a left-leaning thin seam on a steep ramp for about half it's length and then higher steepens as it opens up and gets easier. Near the top it joins Stainless Steel Rat (5.10) and finishes in a slot of sorts.

The protection is adequate on this route and although not quite an "R" rated route you'll definitely have to work to get the gear placed.
content.protection:
Take a good selection of micro-wires, small cams and gear to 2.5" for the belay

HB offsets are quite useful on this route.
content.location:
The obvious left-leaning seam/crack in the center of the face and just left of

Vaino's Crack

.

content.description: A committing steep lieback/fist/offwidth leads up to a hand traverse.  The rock is quite loose.
content.location: Several hundred feet north of Vaino's Crack on a separate rock. It's a left-facing corner leading to a hand traverse left under a roof.

climbs.name: Jumar of Flesh
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon, Alan Roberts, Brian Sillasen, Bob  Jan 1988

content.description: The obvious squeeze chimney starting with a couple of face moves and handcrack, pulling into the bottom of the chimney (a little awkward), then straightforward easy knee and foot chimney, ending with a short bit of crack/face (crux) pulling out of the top of the chimney section. Tops out on a nice big ledge.
content.protection: Single set of cams from #0.75 camalot to 6 Friend. Save a #1 or #2 camalot for the last moves. Anchor takes 1/2" to 3/4" and 3" to 4".
content.location: Located on the highest tier of the west side of the Foundry. Ten feet left of Six Pack Crack. Scramble off climbers' right.

content.description:
In the left-center of the face is an obvious, smooth face with a thin, vertical crack running up it (The Hashish Crack). This climb starts to the right, at a short, left facing corner.

Climb the short, left facing corner to the top.
content.location: In the left-center of the face is an obvious, smooth face with a thin, vertical crack running up it (The Hashish Crack). This climb starts to the right, at a short, left facing corner.

climbs.name: The Crawdad
climbs.fa: Tucker Tech and Alan Bartlett, April 2003

content.description: Short lieback above a bush and then you enter the wide right-leaning squeeze.  Use your head, shoulders, and anything to keep yourself from falling out.  A good intro to squeezes
content.protection: .5 - 6 on BDs.  Smaller sizes for the anchor if you belay before ledge
content.location:
Just to the right around the corner from

Son Volt Arete

.
